passages.text: The success of fecal microbial transplantation in Clostridium difficile infection correlates with bacteriophage relative abundance in the donor: a retrospective cohort study
FMT, intestinal microbiome, bacteriophages, Clostridium difficile infection

Background: Fecal microbial transplantation (FMT) is used in the treatment of relapsing Clostridium difficile infection (rCDI). Failure rate for FMT is as high as 10% but the mechanisms contributing to a failed FMT are not understood. We utilized metagenomic data to identify the role of bacteria and bacteriophages on FMT success.

Results: Subjects with rCDI (n = 19) received FMT from volunteer donors (n = 7) via colonoscopy. Twelve patients fully recovered after a single FMT, while seven patients required a subsequent FMT. DNA was extracted from patient and donor stool samples for shotgun metagenomic analysis. Metagenomics libraries were analyzed focusing on bacterial taxonomy and bacteriophage sequences. Gammaproteobacteria were dominant in rCDI patients prior to FMT largely due to elevated levels of Klebsiella and Escherichia. A successful FMT led to increased levels of Clostridia and Bacteroidia and a reduction in Gammaproteobacteria. In contrast, a failed FMT led to no significant changes in bacterial composition. Bacteriophages were classified during whole metagenomic analysis of each sample and were markedly different between rCDI patients, donors, and a healthy control cohort (n = 96). Bacteriophage sequence reads were increased in CDI patients compared with donors and healthy controls. Successful FMT donors had higher bacteriophage α-diversity and lower relative abundance compared to the donors of a failed initial FMT.

Conclusions: In this retrospective analysis, FMTs with increased bacteriophage α-diversity were more likely to successfully treat rCDI. In addition, the relative number of bacteriophage reads was lower in donations leading to a successful FMT. These results suggest that bacteriophage abundance may have some role in determining the relative success of FMT.

Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) is a common infectious disease with an increasing incidence, mortality and severity over the last decade. Relapsing CDI (rCDI) is rising in incidence and occurs following first-line treatment in 8–50% of subjects1 Fecal microbial transplantation (FMT) is a highly effective therapy for rCDI2 with a response rate of over 80% following a single FMT and up to 90% after a second FMT.3–5 FMT may also have a role in a variety of other diseases, however, the precise mechanisms underlying the effectiveness of FMT in rCDI and other processes remain unclear.6–8

The human gut contains approximately 1015 individual bacteriophage particles with diversity and abundance fluctuating with age and medical comorbidities.9 The role of bacteriophages in the regulation of the gut microbiota is relatively unknown.10 Several studies have characterized the human enteric virome using virus-like particles (VLP) isolated from stool.11-13 Indeed, recent studies showing sterile fecal filtrate to be efficacious in the treatment of rCDI highlight the possibility that non-bacterial contents of FMT, including microbial metabolites and bacteriophages, may be the underlying components responsible for FMT efficacy.14 Zuo et al15 characterized the diversity and richness of a prominent viral order, Caudovirales, in donors and recipients and this viral population’s effect on FMT. In cases of successful FMT, donors had higher Caudovirales richness than the recipients, while in most non-responders, Caudovirales richness was higher than that of the donors.

In the human gut, bacteriophages are predominantly temperate and integrated into bacterial genome as prophages.13,16-19 Prophages can be induced by an environmental factor such as antibiotics, which causes the lysis of the host and release of their viral progenies that may then infect other bacteria.20-23 To date there has been little attention paid to the analysis of bacteriophages and their potential role in FMT efficacy.

Whole genome shotgun metagenomics is a powerful method for detecting bacterial species, estimating microbial diversity and predicting genetic function compared to a 16S amplicon approach.24 It generates its output based on many short sequences obtained from randomly sheared DNA from various microorganisms and the human genome.25 Fecal whole genome shotgun metagenomic libraries contain a vast amount of information on bacterial taxonomy and functional genes as well as viral sequences, which can indicate the presence of bacteriophages.

The aim of this study was to examine both altered bacterial and bacteriophage profiles in patients with rCDI and to determine the effect of bacteriophage populations on FMT efficacy using whole genome shotgun metagenomic analysis.

infons.section_title_2: FMT reduced bacteriophage diversity and relative abundance

passages.text: Nineteen patients with rCDI were included in this study. Patient clinical characteristics are detailed in Table 1. Ultimately, all patients responded successfully to the treatment, with twelve patients responding after a single FMT, and seven patients requiring a second FMT. There were no significant clinical differences between the patients that responded to a single FMT and those which required a second FMT. From donors and rCDI patients a total of 83 metagenomic libraries were constructed using 16 954 954 total sequence reads. As expected, rCDI patients had a significantly lower bacterial α-diversity compared to donors as measured by the Shannon diversity index (Figure 1(a), P ≤ 0.05). Interestingly, the observed reduction of bacterial diversity was inversely altered with the expansion of bacteriophage diversity (Figure 1(b)). The number of bacteriophage reads per million (rpm), or relative abundance, was significantly higher in rCDI patients compared to donors and healthy controls (Figure 1(c,d)). The relative abundance of bacteriophages decreased in patients who recovered after a single successful FMT (Figure 1(c)). In patients requiring a second FMT, a reduction in bacteriophage relative abundance was not observed until after the second FMT (Figure 1(d)). Figure 2 shows the bacteriophage composition in rCDI patients and donors in those patients which responded to a single FMT (Figure 2(a)) and in those which required a second FMT (Figure 2(b)). rCDI patients had a greater diversity of bacteriophages compared with donors.

infons.section_title_2: Alteration of bacterial composition in patients after a successful FMT

passages.text: Prior to FMT, the bacterial profiles of rCDI patients were dominated by Proteobacteria, with Klebsiella and Escherichia being the most abundant genera (Supplementary Figure 1–3). In addition, the classes of Gammaproteobacteria and Bacilli were highly abundant in rCDI patients compared to the abundance of Actinobacteria, Clostridia and Bacteroidia, which were prominent in donor samples (Figure 3(a)). As expected, the bacterial profile of successfully treated rCDI patients more closely resembled that of donor samples, with increased Bacteroidetes and Firmicutes at the expense of Proteobacteria. Specifically, Clostridia and Bacteroidia increased and Gammaproteobacteria decreased in patients who responded to FMT. In contrast, a failed FMT did not shift the bacterial profile of patients towards that of the donor samples (Figure 3(b)). However, after receiving a successful second FMT, the patients’ bacterial profile resembled the donor samples.

infons.section_title_2: Alteration of bacterial composition in patients after a successful FMT

passages.text: Principal coordinate analysis (PCoA) based on Bray-Curtis dissimilarities showed considerable shifts in both the bacteria and bacteriophage profiles of the rCDI patients towards the donor samples (Figure 4). In the cohort which responded to a single FMT, bacteria profiles shifted towards the donors (ADONIS before FMT vs Donor p = 0.00; Before FMT vs After FMT p = 0.001; 999 permutations) (Figure 4(a)). Bacteriophage profiles also shifted toward donor samples in these patients (ADONIS before FMT vs Donor p = 0.001, Before FMT vs After FMT p = 0.001, 999 permutation) (Figure 4(b)).

infons.section_title_2: Alteration of bacterial composition in patients after a successful FMT

passages.text: In the cohort that did not respond to an initial FMT, bacteria (Figure 4(c)) did not significantly shift towards the donors until a successful second FMT was performed (ADONIS 1st After FMT vs 2nd Donor p = 0.003, 1st After FMT vs 2nd After FMT p = 0.035, 999 permutations) (Figure 4(c)). The same pattern was observed for bacteriophages in this cohort (Figure 4(d), ADONIS 1st After FMT vs 2nd Donor p = 0.003; 1st After FMT vs 2nd After FMT p = 0.057, 999 permutations). Interestingly, the bacteriophage populations of successful donations were significantly different compared to unsuccessful donations, suggesting that the relative abundance of bacteriophages may influence the outcome of FMT (ADONIS 1st Donor vs 2nd Donor p = 0.043, 999 permutations).

infons.section_title_2: Donor bacteriophage characteristics associated with efficacy of FMT

passages.text: Bacteriophage relative abundance was significantly higher in rCDI patients compared to donors (p < 0.05) and healthy controls (p < 0.01) (Figure 1(c,d)). Following FMT, bacteriophage relative abundance was significantly decreased in patients who were successfully treated (p < 0.05) (Figure 1(c)), while in patients requiring a second FMT, a significant reduction in bacteriophage relative abundance was not observed until after the second FMT (Figure 1(d)). While there were no apparent differences in bacteriophage populations in rCDI patients who responded to therapy after a single FMT and those who did not, we did identify differences in the bacteriophage characteristics of stool donations stratified by therapeutic success. The α-diversity of bacteriophage communities in donor stools that led to disease resolution was significantly higher than the α-diversity of failed FMT donations (p < 0.05) (Figure 5(a)), while richness was lower in successful donations (Figure 5(b)). In addition, bacteriophage relative abundance was elevated in failed FMT donations compared to successful donations (p < 0.05) (Figure 5(c)). It is important to note that no single donor was associated with most of the failures (Supplementary Table 1). The change in bacteriophage relative abundance in recipients before FMT to after FMT correlated with the donor sample bacteriophage relative abundance (r = 0.6 p < 0.01) (Figure 5(d)). Finally, recipients receiving donations with a high relative number of bacteriophage reads (RPM>3142) were more likely to recur than those with a lower bacteriophage abundance. Indeed, 5 of 9 ‘high’ (RPM>3142) bacteriophage donations led to recurrence, while 2/18 ‘low’ (RPM<3142) bacteriophage donations recurred.

FMT is an efficacious treatment for rCDI, although 10–20% do not responded to an initial FMT.26 Multiple studies have demonstrated that a successful FMT normalizes the gut microbiota and shifts its composition toward healthy donor profiles,27,28 but there has been limited attention directed toward the effect of FMT on bacteriophage populations.11 In this study, we used shotgun metagenomic data to examine the relationship between FMT efficacy and the relative abundance of bacteriophages in fecal donations.

The proposed mechanisms underlying the ability of FMT to restore microbial diversity and effectively treat rCDI includes the direct interaction between donor microbes and resident C. difficile, along with microbe-induced stimulation of host immune function, competition for nutrients, and inhibition of C. difficile growth by secondary bile acids.29 Most luminal microbes are anaerobic or aerotolerant bacteria. These bacteria consume reactive oxygen species produced by aerobic host metabolism.30 Accordingly, many members of Actinobacteria and Proteobacteria are equipped with several genes for enzymes such as catalase and superoxide dismutase that can inactivate reactive oxygen species.30 rCDI patients in this study had a profound dysbiosis with enrichment of Proteobacteria, a phyla capable of aerobic metabolism. FMT treatment may restore anaerobic bacteria including Clostridia and Bacteroidia at the expense of Gammaproteobacteria in rCDI patients.

In this work we demonstrate that rCDI patients demonstrated an increased proportion of bacteriophages, a finding which may have been driven by extensive antibiotic usage. Clinical studies have shown a progressive loss of microbial diversity in patients with rCDI that is directly related to the duration of antibiotic treatment.31 Other studies have shown that sub-lethal concentrations of several different antibiotics can stimulate virulent bacteriophages.32-34 Mechanisms underlying antibiotic-induced prophage induction include activation of the SOS stress response and the production of reactive oxygen species.35,36 Indeed, both fluoroquinolones and β-lactams have been shown to induce prophages both in vitro and in vivo.33,36 Interestingly, studies have also shown that antibiotics can increase the expression of genes involved in prophage induction and cause a loss of certain bacteria, specifically in the Clostridia class, which may contribute to the outgrowth of pathogenic C. difficile.32 Further, studies have demonstrated that antibiotic treatment can also result in the enrichment of phage-encoded genes that confer antibiotic resistance to the host and resistance to microbes growing under aerobic conditions.36 Although our data does not suggest that the bacteriophage populations in FMT recipients are predictive of remission, the finding that rCDI patients possess an increased abundance of bacteriophage may be related to the pathogenicity of C. difficile via the disruption of normal microbial communities in this disease.

Zuo et al15 demonstrated a potential role for bacteriophages in the success of FMT in treating C. difficile. High richness within the Caudovirales clade in donor samples was an important factor in predicting successful FMT. In contrast, increased richness of the recipient’s virome was correlated with recurrence after FMT. In our study, bacteriophage diversity decreased following a successful FMT. However, an initial unsuccessful FMT did not decrease the relative abundance of bacteriophages. It is especially noteworthy the diversity of bacteriophages in successful FMT donations was higher than in donations leading to a failed FMT, and that the relative abundance of bacteriophages in successful donations was lower than in failed donations.

Bacteriophages are elemental components of human microbiomes in the gut, skin, lung, and urinary tract.37 Humans are exposed to immensely diverse populations of bacteria and phages. Despite the ubiquitous presence of bacteriophages throughout our bodies, the interaction with human cells, infection pathways, and the immune system is still not well known. Fortunately, the viral database for metagenomic analysis of bacteriophages is advancing each year, yielding more robust results for this type of analysis. However, viral databases are still not near comprehensive, and therefore results drawn from these types of analysis must acknowledge that there may be potentially important viral populations that are not yet represented. Moreover, the low relative abundance of virophage sequences in whole metagenomics libraries makes difficult de novo assembly of viral sequences into contigs, which would increase specificity of taxonomic classifications and phylogenetic analysis.38 Individual or assembled phage sequences can be queried upon translation against protein databases, either using direct alignments or more sophisticated methods like those using hidden Markov models, but this often results in false positive hits.38 A further bioinformatics complication of phage genomics is that their genome encodes a large fraction of proteins (ca. 80%) unrelated to other known proteins.39 Furthermore, the identified bacteriophages may be derived from sources other than typical bacteriophages. For example, they may represent contaminations or spacers of CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats). CRISPR has been identified as a form of bacterial adaptive immunity against bacteriophage infection and foreign DNA as plasmid DNA.40,41 Limitations to this work include the retrospective nature of the analysis and also the small sample size. In addition, there also exists the possibility that donations which failed may have had reduced viability due to technical reasons which may not have been apparent through metagenomic analysis. Moreover, phage populations were surveyed in whole metagenomics libraries and their low relative abundance compared to bacterial sequences might allow only an incomplete portrait of their abundance and diversity. In-parallel construction of libraries from viral filtrates would offer a better screening method, but it increases costs significantly. Deeper sequencing of libraries would also increase resolution of phage populations. Thus, we do acknowledge that we might be looking only at the tip of the iceberg. Nevertheless, our data allowed clear detection of greater diversity and lower relative abundance of phage sequences in fecal microbial preparations that led to successful FMT.

Ultimately, this work represents a novel analysis of bacteriophages in recurrent Clostridium difficile infection. We identify that patients with rCDI possess an increased number and diversity of bacteriophages which are reduced following successful treatment with FMT. We also identify that a decreased bacteriophage relative abundance and increased bacteriophage α-diversity in the donor stool was associated with disease resolution. Further studies involving larger population sizes are required to fully understand how bacteriophage content in both donors and recipients influences FMT results.

This study was conducted at the University of Alberta Hospital in Edmonton, Alberta between October of 2012 and November of 2014 and was approved by the University of Alberta Health Research Ethics Board. 19 patients aged 35 to 85 with rCDI, defined by at least 3 episodes of CDI within 6 months were included. Active CDI was defined as diarrhea (>3 loose stools per day) with positive stool C difficile toxin test. All patients and stool donors provided written consent to participate in the study. FMT success was defined as resolution of diarrhea without a need for anti-CDI therapy or another FMT within 8 weeks of treatment. In the event of FMT failure, a second FMT was offered from a different stool donor. Twelve patients responded after a single FMT, and seven patients required a second FMT. Data from 96 healthy individuals between the ages of 18 and 40 were downloaded from the Human Microbiome Project (HMP) Consortium (2012) for comparing amounts of viral like sequence with donors in this study [https://portal.hmpdacc.org/search].

To prepare for FMT, patients with rCDI discontinued vancomycin for 24 hours and received 4L of polyethylene glycol-based bowel preparation (GoLYTELY®) before colonoscopy-delivered FMT. Stool for FMT was obtained from one of seven volunteer stool donors registered with the Edmonton FMT program, administered either fresh or frozen-and-thawed (Supplementary Table 1). Donor selection process, preparation and banking of fecal slurry and patient follow-up has been described previously.42

infons.section_title_2: DNA extraction and whole genome shotgun sequencing

passages.text: The Qiagen QIAamp DNA stool kit (QIAGEN Inc, CA USA) was used to extract total genomic DNA as per the manufacturer’s protocol. DNA was quantified using a PICO green assay and extracted DNA used for the Illumina Nextera® XT DNA Sample Preparation Kit to construct indexed paired-end DNA shotgun libraries. The pooled and indexed microbiome libraries were sequenced on an Illumina MiSeq platform (Illumina, CA USA).

infons.section_title_2: DNA extraction and whole genome shotgun sequencing

passages.text: Quality control of sequences was conducted with the FASTX-Toolkit (http://hannonlab.cshl.edu/fastx_toolkit/index.html). In brief, bases with quality scores smaller than 25 (Q < 25) were trimmed off and reads shorter than 250 nt were discarded. Assembly of paired-end reads was carried out with PEAR (http://sco.h-its.org/exelixis/web/software/pear/).

infons.section_title_2: Bacterial taxonomic and bacteriophage sequences profiling

passages.text: Taxonomy of sequences was resolved using a Kraken Version 0.10.4-beta and the database Minikrakendb,43 supplemented with the virus database of NCBI. The analysis followed the Microbiome Helper workflow (https://github.com/mlangill/microbiome_helper/wiki).44 The mapped sequence counts, read counts and total sequence counts were used to normalize the sequence counts and represent the reads per million (RPM) of each sample. The dataset(s) supporting the conclusions of this article are available in the NCBI SRA repository, Accession codes: BioProject PRJNA454892 and SRA Study SRP144704. The bacterial taxonomic and viral sequences abundance data were imported into R 3.2.3 to analyze for richness, diversity, heatmap and ordination plot (PCoA: Principal Coordinate analysis) and were performed using a function of the phyloseq package.45 PERMANOVA test was used to determine the statistical significance of sample grouping from PCoA. (R-phyloseq package based on vegan function adonis). FMT donations were obtained from seven separate donors over a period of 24 months and were considered as separate samples for statistical purposes given the intra-individual variability observed over time. Statistical significance testing was determined by the Mann Whitney and Kruskal-Wallis test with Dunn’s correction comparing samples in this study using Graphpad Prism 6.

This study was approved by the University of Alberta Health Research Ethics Board. All patients and stool donors provided written consent to participate in the study. No identifiable individual data is provided in this manuscript. Datasets used and analyzed in this study are available from the corresponding author upon request. The authors report no competing interests.

Funding was provided by Alberta Heath Solutions to Dina Kao and Karen Madsen; Canadian Institutes of Health Research to Karen Madsen; and Alberta Innovates to Heekuk Park. Author contributions are the following: KM, HP designed the study; DK recruited and treated patients; HP, JJ, ML performed the sequencing and interpreted results; NH, JY, BM interpreted data and provided critical revision of the manuscript; HP, ML and KM wrote the manuscript; JJ, BM, JH, and DK provided intellectual content in the writing of the manuscript. The authors would like to acknowledgment the contributions of Matt Emberg and Brandi Roach to the fecal microbial transplant program at the University of Alberta and The Applied Genomic Center at the University of Alberta for sequencing. Infrastructure support was provided by the Center of Excellence for Gastrointestinal Inflammation and Immunity Research.
Supplemental data for this article can be accessed on the publisher’s website.
